This report was prepared by W. Lincklaen Arriens, lead water resources specialist, RSAN 
 
(Chair,  Water  Sector  Committee)  with  input  from  the  members  of  the  Water  Sector 
 
Committee.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  On 16 January 2001, the Board of Directors approved the water policy1 of the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB),  following  extensive  consultations  with  stakeholders  over  several 
years.  In  addition  to  promoting  national  water  sector  reforms,  integrated  water  resources 
management, and better water services for the poor, the policy commits ADB to regional and 
subregional cooperation by assisting with water sector assessments and exchange of data, 
enhancing awareness and understanding of the water sector issues and needs of each country, 
and supporting water partnerships in ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs).  
 
2.  On 10 December 2001, the Board approved the establishment of the Cooperation Fund 
for the Water Sector.  The Fund is a multidonor umbrella facility to promote effective water 
management policies and practices at the regional, subregional, and country levels and thereby 
to catalyze the implementation of ADB’s water policy in the Asia and Pacific region.  The Fund will 
finance a coherent program of activities designed to add value to the water projects carried out by 
ADB’s regional departments. The activities will increase synergy in ADB’s water sector operations 
as a whole through better awareness, knowledge management, capacity building to support 
generic sector reforms, pilot demonstration, regional cooperation, monitoring, and coordination. 
The Program aims to add value to ADB’s water operations, and the Fund is not intended to 
replace resources for regular operational activities.  
 
3.  In December 2001, the  Government of the Netherlands made an initial contribution of 
$4 million  to  the  Fund  for  the  Program’s  activities  in  2002,  for  which  technical  assistance 
(TA) 6031-REG was approved by ADB’s Board.2 The initial contribution of $4 million has been 
committed, and the activities approved under the TA cover all six approved categories of the 
Program,  including  (i)  promotion  and  public  awareness;  (ii)  knowledge  base  and  capacity 
building; (iii) pilot and demonstrations; (iv) water partnerships; (v) regional events and initiatives; 
and (vi) program coordination, monitoring, and evaluation.  
 
4.  The Government of the Netherlands made a second contribution to the Fund in December 
2002  in  the  amount  of  $4  million,  and  the  Government  of  Norway  has  agreed  to  provide 
approximately  $2  million  equivalent  over  3  years  starting  in  2003.  Donor  contributions  are 
generally  made  in  annual  tranches,  and  these  are  accessed  through  regional  TA  projects. 
ADB's Water Sector Committee has recommended that two regional TAs be processed in 2003 to 
support  the  Program’s  further  activities.  Accordingly,  TA  6093-REG  was  approved  by 
ADB’s Board to support the organization of the 3rd World Water Forum (WWF) held in Japan on 
16-23 March 2003.3 This proposed second TA has been prepared to support other activities of 
the Program. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.4  
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  The Board paper establishing the Fund identified three areas of priority assistance in the 
implementation of ADB’s water policy and the national water policies in the Asia and Pacific 
region.  The first area is assistance to DMCs for water sector assessments and national water 
action agendas, to design and implement critical water sector reforms; and for demonstrating 
these  reforms  through  pilot  initiatives  at  the  appropriate  levels,  involving  national  water 
partnerships and river basin organizations to ensure broad stakeholder participation.  The second 
area concerns revising ADB’s business processes and strengthening its internal capacity to target 
the water sector more holistically in its operations, with greater synergy through knowledge 
management  and  collaboration  with  development  partners.  The  third  area  is  to  strengthen

regional cooperation and awareness of important water issues, trends, and policies, and to 
catalyze  a  new  generation  of  water  sector  investments  that  follow  from  effective  water 
management policies and sector reforms.  The Millennium Development Goals adopted at the 
World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg in 2002 underline the urgency of 
helping to improve the water security of the poor through safe drinking water, improved sanitation, 
water  for  production  and  income  generation,  sustainable  environmental  management,  and 
reduced vulnerability to water-related disasters.      
 
6.  To prioritize the use of the Fund in response to these needs, the Water Sector Committee 
has  coordinated  the  Program’s  activities  in  the  six  categories,  therein  supported  by 
five subcommittees. A steering committee comprising directors of the concerned divisions in 
ADB’s regional departments and Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
has provided overall guidance and supervision to the Program’s direction and activities, and has 
approved the detailed design and implementation arrangements of major components with an 
estimated cost of over $400,000. Upon the request of the steering committee, the Water Sector 
Committee has prepared a medium-term strategy for activities financed from the Fund. This 
strategy will be updated in response to evolving needs for assistance and lessons learned in 
DMCs and ADB in implementing ADB’s water policy. The initial progress of the Program is 
summarized  in  Appendix  2.  Progress  is  also  being  published  on  ADB’s  water  web  site, 
http://www.adb.org/water. 
 
7.  Funding  requests  from  ADB’s  regional  departments  for  activities  in  the  DMCs  have 
increased significantly during the past year, and the main lesson learned in administering the 
Fund is to organize the delegation of activities to regional departments in response to their 
specific  demands,  while  maintaining  the  principle  of  additionality  in  the  use  of  the  Fund. 
Procedures and guidelines have been developed to accommodate and prioritize funding requests 
from DMCs and ADB staff. Coordination was established with the other multilateral development 
banks that have similar funding facilities. Joint reviews of the Fund’s activities by ADB and 
contributing donors are expected to start in January 2004 in conjunction with ADB’s second 
“Water Week”. A comprehensive review of the Fund is expected in 2005 in conjunction with the 
comprehensive review of ADB’s water policy implementation in that year. 
  
8.  To promote water awareness and strengthen regional cooperation among DMCs and ADB 
in the water sector, the Program has supported the organization of the 3rd WWF in March 2003, 
which was convened to raise awareness of the critical water issues of the looming water crisis in 
the 21st century, and to mobilize actions and resources to address these issues. President Chino 
led ADB’s delegation to the 3rd WWF, and the results of ADB’s participation are reported in a 
separate Board information paper and published on ADB’s water web site.  
 
9.  Additional TA resources are required from the Fund to continue the Program’s activities in 
each of the six categories, in accordance with the medium-term strategy prepared by the Water 
Sector Committee, and in response to requests by ADB’s regional departments.  
 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output  
10.  The proposed TA will continue the Program to promote effective water management 
policies and practices at regional, subregional, and country levels and thereby catalyze the 
implementation of ADB’s water policy in the Asia and Pacific region, including within ADB itself. 
Poverty reduction is an objective crosscutting the proposed activities. The proposed Program 
activities are targeted at a range of stakeholders in the region, including policy makers, planners, 
water  service  providers  and  resource  managers,  ADB’s  decision  makers,  civil  society

3 
 
organizations, the media, the public at large, ADB staff, and development partners. The Program 
includes follow-up initiatives to the 3rd WWF and will help ADB and DMCs achieve the MDGs 
related to water and poverty reduction. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The proposed TA comprises the following activities under the six Program categories.  
 
12.  Promotion and Public Awareness.  ADB’s  Water  Awareness  Program  that  was 
launched in 2002 under TA 6031 will be further developed to disseminate ADB’s water policy and 
key development messages in the water sector, increase  public awareness and stakeholder 
dialogue on water reform issues, improve press coverage of water issues and initiatives, educate 
youth about the water crisis,  and support community-level water education  pilot activities in 
ADB-financed water  projects in the DMCs. The Water Awareness Program will also support 
follow-up initiatives to the 3rd WWF and promote water awareness activities as integral parts of 
national water sector reform processes and of individual water sector projects in the DMCs.  
 
13.  Knowledge Base and Capacity Building. Further support will be given to developing 
ADB’s water information and knowledge management systems to support its water operations, 
and to assist regional departments in undertaking water sector assessments and preparation of 
water sector roadmaps. The systems will use the Internet as well as an intranet for ADB and 
DMC staff use, as part of ADB’s knowledge management initiatives. Further support will be given 
to  comparative  analysis  of  water  sector  reforms  in  the  region,  including  (i)  water  sector 
assessments and the preparation of national water sector profiles and water sector roadmaps; 
(ii) studies on water governance, involving the establishment and performance of water sector 
apex bodies, water policies, water laws, water sector action agendas, river basin organizations, 
and diagnostic methods to assess the capacity and performance of water sector agencies; and 
(iii) comparative studies to support follow-up initiatives to the 3rd WWF, as prioritized by the Water 
Sector Committee.  A water sector capacity building program will be initiated to enhance core 
competencies in DMCs and ADB to implement water policy reforms.  
 
14.  Pilot and Demonstration Activities. Support will be given for introducing and validating 
new or innovative development approaches that are highly replicable. Most of this support will go 
to water project teams in ADB's regional departments, and will strengthen core operations 
including policy dialogue, country programming, and project preparation and implementation. 
Support  will  also  be  given  to  field-based  applied  research  by  local  stakeholders,  including 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and where possible using the regional technical advisory 
committees of the Global Water Partnership (GWP). Examples of preferred topics are (i) national 
and local reform processes, (ii) approaches to effective awareness and community education 
programs, (iii) appropriate technology, (iv) gender and development approaches, (v) participatory 
and inclusive approaches, (vi) connecting services to the poor, and (vii) civil society actions for 
good water governance. Pilot and demonstration activity results will guide and encourage positive 
change among water sector stakeholders and will inform policy dialogue between ADB and the 
DMCs.  
 
15.  Water Partnerships. Several activities will be supported on a demand basis to initiate or 
strengthen national and regional water partnerships. Examples can include the Southeast Asia 
Water Utilities Network, the Network of Asian River Basin Organizations, the Gender in Water 
Partnership, and assistance to the countries of the lower Mekong River basin in the development 
of a flood management partnership in collaboration with the Mekong River Commission and the 
Royal  Netherlands  Embassy  in  Hanoi.  The  development  of  national  and  regional  water 
partnerships can be supported in collaboration with the GWP.

4       
16.  Regional  Events  and  Initiatives.  Support  will  be  provided  on  a  demand  basis  for 
ADB’s follow-up initiatives to the 3rd WWF in the DMCs, including the Water for Asian Cities 
Program, the Water for the Poor–Partnerships for Action, the Network of Asian River Basin 
Organizations, the Gender in  Water Partnership, and other initiatives prioritized by the Water 
Sector Committee. The level of support for each initiative will be determined by the demand in the 
DMCs. Support will also be provided to the organization of ADB’s “Water Weeks”, for ADB’s 
water dialogue with NGOs, for dialogues among neighboring DMCs on common reform issues, 
and  for  thematic  workshops  and  subregional  water  forums  that  help  to  catalyze  the 
implementation of ADB’s water policy in the region, as requested by the regional departments.  
 
17.  Program  Coordination,  Monitoring,  and  Evaluation.  The  monitoring  and  reporting 
system for the Fund will be further developed and maintained to provide updated information on 
inputs, outputs, outcomes, and financial management. ADB’s water web site will play a central 
role in the monitoring and reporting system. The comprehensive review of ADB’s water policy 
implementation in 2005 will be supported. An annual review of the Program’s activities will also 
be organized with the Fund’s contributors in conjunction with ADB’s “Water Weeks”. The water 
focal point in RSDD will be supported to continue the administration, coordination, monitoring, 
and technical support of the Program. Coordination with the other multilateral development banks 
will also be continued.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA, estimated at $4.3 million, will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Cooperation  Fund  for  the  Water  Sector  through  the  channel  financing  facilities  of  the 
governments  of  the  Netherlands,  for  $3 million,  and  Norway,  for  $1.3  million,  and  will  be 
administered by ADB.5  The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The TA will be implemented by ADB. The Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Social 
Sector  Division  (RSAN)  of  RSDD,  in  association  with  concerned  divisions  in  the  regional 
departments and the Office of External Relations (OER), will be responsible for all TA activities. 
The Water Sector Committee will serve as the TA team, in consultation with the Water Sector 
Network. The lead water resources specialist of RSAN will coordinate the team’s activities. TA 
activities  can  be  proposed  by  government  agencies  and  NGOs  in  the  DMCs,  by  other 
development partners, and by ADB staff. Activity proposals will be reviewed and prioritized by the 
Water Sector Committee according to criteria and procedures published on ADB’s water web site. 
The  initiation  and  implementation  of  TA  activities  will  be  delegated  to  operations  divisions 
concerned as appropriate, with administrative and technical support provided by the water focal 
point in RSAN. The existing steering committee comprising directors of the concerned divisions in 
ADB’s regional departments, OER, and RSDD will supervise the TA activities and use of the 
Fund,  including  its  medium-term  strategy,  and  will  approve  the  detailed  design  and 
implementation arrangements of major components of the TA prior to their commencement.6  
 
20.  The water focal point in RSAN will serve as TA office. Approximately 50 person-months of 
international and 173 person-months of domestic consultants will be needed for the regional

are expected to include water policy and legal reform, institutional development, capacity building, 
knowledge management, information systems, water supply and sanitation, integrated water 
resources  management  and  river  basin  organizations,  flood  management  and  insurance, 
managing environmental flows in rivers, watershed management, national poverty reduction 
strategies,  gender  and  development,  public  awareness  and  consultations,  community 
organizations, dams and development, public-private partnerships, tariff reform and regulatory 
frameworks, financing for water infrastructure and services, and related water sector reform 
areas. Coordination and implementation of the TA will be supported by a water policy adviser, 
water operations adviser, contracts administrator, finance manager, database analyst, web site 
manager, and administrative assistant, financed by the TA. Further short-term international and 
domestic consultants may be recruited to fill gaps in the TA team’s expertise. The required 
consultants will mostly be recruited as individuals.8 In the case of activity proposals selected by 
the Water Sector Committee for follow-up initiatives to the 3rd WWF, pilot and demonstration 
activities, water partnership support, and for regional events and initiatives, consulting services by 
international and national organizations and NGOs will be directly selected. ADB will recruit the 
consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements 
satisfactory to ADB for the recruitment of domestic consultants. Outline terms of reference are 
shown in Appendix 4. Equipment and materials to be financed by the TA will be procured by the 
consultants or ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement or other procedures 
acceptable to ADB.9  
 
21.  Participation  in  the  TA  is  open  to  all  of  ADB’s  DMCs.  Each  participating  DMC  will 
designate the water sector apex body, or agency assigned to coordinate water sector activities, 
as the national counterpart agency; this agency will coordinate the country’s participation in the 
TA activities, drawing on the interest and expertise of relevant water stakeholders in the country, 
including those from central and provincial agencies, river basins, the private sector, NGOs, the 
academe, research and professional organizations, and other interested parties. DMCs can make 
proposals for TA activities through the regional departments in ADB for review and prioritization 
by ADB’s Water Sector Committee. 
 
22.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 18 months, commencing in September 2003 
and ending in February 2005. Progress reports on the Program and use of the Fund will be 
prepared by the water focal point in RSAN on a six-monthly basis in collaboration with the Office 
of Cofinancing Operations. TA activities will be monitored and reports made available through the 
ADB water web site.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
23.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $4,300,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector for Promoting Effective Water Management Policies and 
Practices—Phase 3.

COOPERATION FUND FOR THE WATER SECTOR 
SUMMARY OF PROGRESS 
 
1.    Promotion and Public Awareness. The first phase of the Water Awareness Program 
(WAP) has supported the participation of the Asian Development Bank  (ADB) in the World 
Summit on Sustainable Development and the 3rd World Water Forum (WWF). Outputs included 
a series of television documentaries, web site development (http://www.adb.org/water), briefs on 
water  issues,  publicity  materials,  public  service  announcements,  print  publications,  media 
relations, and exhibitions.  More than 18,000 WAP outputs were distributed at the 3rd WWF. 
Several improvements and updates on the web site continue since its launching in 2002. Plans 
have been initiated for a second phase of the WAP.   
 
2.    Knowledge Base and Capacity Building. Several initiatives were undertaken to start 
knowledge management, including the formation of the Water Sector Network, a participatory 
capacity assessment, the design of a water information system for use by ADB and developing 
member country (DMC) staff in support of ADB’s water operations, and comparative studies on 
several topics including water in Asian cities. Guidelines were also developed for water sector 
roadmaps in DMCs.  
 
3.    Pilot and Demonstration Activities.  Pilot and demonstration activities (PDAs) were 
initiated in 2002 and the demand from ADB’s regional departments for support for such activities 
has grown rapidly. Figures A2.1-A2.3 show the distribution of pilot and demonstration activities 
approved by the Water Sector Committee, by subregion, subsector, and type. After gaining 
experience with the first batch of activities, the Water Sector Committee adopted guidelines for 
selection of such activities in May 2003.

4.    Water Partnerships. Several activities were undertaken to initiate or strengthen national 
and regional water partnerships in the Pacific, Southeast Asia, and Mekong. In the Pacific 
region, an existing partnership of atoll island countries affected by climate change and the rise 
in sea level was supported through a pilot study on national water resources assessment and 
coastal zone planning for Kiribati.  Support was provided to the Global Water Partnership 
Southeast Asia Technical Advisory Committee for strengthening community-based institutions 
that have demonstrated replicable and sustainable strategies in integrated water resources 
management in five countries in the region and for documenting their activities. Funds were 
allocated  to  support  the  countries  of  the  lower  Mekong  River  basin  in  their  new  flood 
management initiative, with ADB support focusing on the poverty reduction interventions as part 
of the initiative.   
 
5.    Regional  Events  and  Initiatives.  The  participation  of  ADB  in  the  3rd  WWF  was 
supported to help promote the mi plementation of ADB’s water policy in the region. ADB’s 
participation (i) showcased projects in DMCs; (ii) provided knowledge, experience, and lessons 
learned; (iii) supported DMCs to participate and learn; (iv) strengthened collaboration with 
partners; and (v) increased awareness and raised ADB’s profile. ADB organized five themes: 
(i) Water and Poverty, (ii) Water and Cities, (iii) Water in Small Island Countries, (iv) Poverty and 
Floods, and (v) Regional Cooperation for Shared Water Resources Management in central Asia.  
ADB organized 15 thematic sessions, participated in the World Panel on Financing Water 
Infrastructure, and convened the Water Development Partners Panel. ADB also participated in 
and supported regional initiatives, such as on water rights; dialogue for water, food, and 
environment; and water governance. 
 
6.   Program  Coordination,  Monitoring,  and  Evaluation.  The  use  of  the  Fund  is 
coordinated by the Water Sector Committee and supported by ADB’s water focal point located 
in  the  Agriculture,  Natural  Resources  and  Social  Sectors  Division,  according  to  the 
medium-term strategy for the Fund. A steering committee comprising directors of the concerned 
operations divisions in ADB’s regional departments provides overall guidance and supervision 
to the Program activities, and approves the detailed design and implementation arrangements 
of major Program components. Figure A2.4 shows the organization structure for implementing 
the Fund.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The outline terms of reference for consultants describe the main tasks in each of the 
six categories of the program of activities to promote effective water management policies and 
practices in the region and thereby catalyze implementation of the water policy of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) in the Asia and Pacific region. The six categories are promotion and 
public  awareness;  knowledge  base  and  capacity  building;  pilot  demonstration;  water 
partnerships;  regional  events  and  initiatives;  and  program  coordination,  monitoring,  and 
evaluation.  Poverty  reduction  is  a  crosscutting  priority  in  all  tasks.  ADB’s  Water  Sector 
Committee will guide the program of activities, which are coordinated by the Agriculture, Natural 
Resources, and Social Sector Division (RSAN). 
 
A.  Promotion and Public Awareness  
2.  An international  public relations specialist will be engaged on an individual basis for 
1 year to manage the second phase of ADB’s water awareness program (WAP). The WAP’s 
objectives, in continuation of  its first phase, are to (i) promote public understanding of water 
issues and disseminate ADB’s water policy, (ii) facilitate dialogue among water stakeholders on 
the water reform agenda in the region, (iii) help educate children and youth on water issues and 
their role in finding solutions, and (iv) support small pilot and demonstration activities for 
community water education.   
 
3.  In its second phase, the WAP will continue to use a range of suitable tools and activities 
to communicate a range of messages effectively to different target audiences, including (i) water 
sector stakeholders and decision makers, (ii) children and youth, (iii) poor communities, and 
(iv) the general public in the Asia and Pacific region. The WAP will also help to strengthen 
ADB’s collaboration with the media in reaching these target audiences. The development 
messages will be derived from ADB’s water policy, from the results of the 3rd World Water 
Forum (WWF), and from other key water themes in coordination with development partners.  
 
4.  The  tools  and  activities  will  include  ADB’s  water  web  site,  a  regional  electronic 
newsletter, print publications, publicity materials and photographs, television documentaries and 
video productions, public service announcements, media relations and networking, exhibitions, 
pilot  community  education  activities,  other  pilot  activities  to  promote  water  awareness  in 
developing member countries (DMCs), and other complementary activities as determined by the 
Water Sector Committee and the WAP team. The design and implementation arrangements of 
the second phase of WAP will be approved by the technical assistance (TA) steering committee 
prior to the start of implementation. 
 
5.  To help implement the WAP, international specialists (with expertise in public and media 
relations;  multimedia  production;  and  information,  education,  and  communication)  will  be 
engaged on an individual basis to work in the WAP team. They will work together with domestic 
consultants, including a web site manager, media relations and  networking specialists, and 
other  specialists  as  needed,  who  will  also  be  engaged  on  an  individual  basis.  In  close 
collaboration with ADB’s Office of External Relations, the Water Sector Committee and network, 
and other operations staff in the regional departments, the WAP team will work in RSAN to 
undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist ADB staff in the further development and effective use of key development 
messages related to water sector issues and themes, covering water and poverty 
reduction, effective water policies; issues related to water service delivery and

B.  Knowledge Base and Capacity Building  
8.  International water policy and institutional development specialists will be engaged on an 
individual and intermittent basis to do the following: 
 
(i)  Advise staff in ADB’s regional departments on supporting country water sector 
assessments, strategies, policy dialogue, and reforms.  
(ii)  Conduct thematic and comparative analyses of ongoing water sector reforms in 
the region, including studies on water governance, involving the establishment 
and performance of water sector apex bodies, water policies, water laws, water 
sector action agendas, river basin organizations, regulatory bodies, and other 
water institutions. 
(iii)  Organize capacity development programs for ADB and DMC staff on important 
water issues and skills, drawing on the results of the capacity and training needs 
assessments carried out in 2002, including training seminars and workshops, 
participation  in  training  courses,  recommendations  for  country  exchange 
dialogues on priority water sector reform topics, the strengthening of ADB’s water 
focal point, and the development of regional research and capacity building 
networks in accordance with ADB’s water policy. 
(iv)  Conduct  follow-up  studies  building  on  the  results  of  the  3rd  WWF,  e.g.,  in 
financing of water infrastructure, the role of small-scale independent service 
providers, and other subjects as determined by the Water Sector Committee.   
 
9.  The  international  specialists  will  work  with  full-time  domestic  specialists  in  RSAN, 
including a water policy adviser and a water operations adviser, who will also be engaged on an 
individual basis. These domestic specialists will also be responsible to develop existing ADB 
data bases into an integrated water sector information system for use by ADB and DMC staff, 
through the intranet and Internet, to support ADB’s water operations. The system will provide 
water sector statistics by DMC, including national water sector profiles, policies, laws, and 
sector roadmaps for DMCs; a compilation of useful practices in key water sector reform topics 
and on poverty reduction in water sector operations; and links to  water knowledge centers 
outside  ADB.  These  systems  will  be  developed  as  part  of  a  Water  Net  under  ADB’s 
“communities of practice” approach to knowledge management. 
 
10.  Services  for  knowledge  base  and  capacity  building  are  expected  to  comprise 
approximately  12  person-months  of  international  and  42  person-months  of  domestic 
consultants.  
 
C.  Pilot and Demonstration Activities 
11.  International  and/or  domestic  short-term  water  sector  specialists  (with  expertise  as 
required)  will  be  engaged  on  an  individual  basis  to  support  regional  department  staff  in 
conducting  pilot  and  demonstration  activities  (PDAs)  in  DMCs,  according  to  guidelines 
developed  by  the  Water  Sector  Committee.  PDAs  will  mostly  complement  ADB  water 
operations. They should be driven by the needs of ADB’s regional departments and project 
officers, who develop the proposals for activities to be supported by the Fund.

Appendix 4  17
 
12.  Water sector roadmaps prepared under ADB’s country strategy and program process 
highlight  expected  changes  and  achievements  in  the  water  sector.  These  development 
expectations may require the introduction of new ideas, technologies, and approaches to the 
sector. The changes may be at the national level (e.g., achieving national policy and reform 
outcomes)  down  to  the  local  level  (e.g.,  achieving  widespread  application  of  market-level 
technologies, approaches, and arrangements). Changes may also be possible in more than one 
country. Bringing innovation to bear involves (i) research and experimentation to validate the 
innovation, and (ii) advocacy to ensure decision makers and other stakeholders agree to the 
changes. The PDAs supported by the Fund should therefore introduce and validate new or 
innovative approaches that are highly replicable.  
 
13.  PDAs will mostly involve consultant services to support ADB missions in developing, 
validating, and demonstrating new approaches during the processing and implementation of 
project preparation and advisory TA, and loan-financed  investment  projects.  Activities  can 
include field-based applied research and demonstration, which are likely to be proposed by local 
stakeholders, including NGOs.       
 
14.  PDAs are generally expected to test or highlight new approaches, confirm their efficacy, 
and then implement or plan a replication program. PDAs could be processed in connection with 
changes in (i) national or local water policy reform processes, (ii) water awareness program 
approaches,  (iii)  appropriate  technology,  (iv)  gender  and  development  approaches, 
(v) participatory and inclusive approaches and multistakeholder representation, (vi) connecting 
services to the poor, and (vii) other changes catalyzed by ADB’s water policy.  PDAs can be 
related to the management of water resources and the delivery of water services. 
 
15.  The  maximum  amount  to  be  drawn  from  the  Fund  will  normally  not  exceed 
$50,000 equivalent. The average implementation period for a PDA is expected to be 6 months, 
and the maximum allowable implementation period is 12 months. PDAs should not duplicate 
ongoing or pipelined activity in the DMC. PDAs should be directly relevant to the “sector 
outcomes” cited in the country strategy program/country strategy program updates for the DMC. 
If the start of a PDA is unduly delayed, the Water Sector Committee can decide that the Funds 
committed will be reallocated to other PDAs on the waiting list. 
 
16.  In prioritizing between requests for PDAs, the Water Sector Committee will consider the 
following criteria (i) originality, (ii) replicability, (iii) potential replicability (in case of pilot test), 
(iv) lessons learned, (v) pro-poor focus, (vi) participatory development and gender  inclusion, 
(vii) operations support, (viii) collaborative approach using partnerships, (ix) technically strong 
design, and (x) consistency with ADB’s water policy. 
 
17.  The type and duration of consulting inputs for the pilot and demonstration activities will 
be provided in the activity proposals to be submitted by concerned departments in ADB during 
TA implementation.

D.  Water Partnerships 
18.  International and/or domestic short-term water sector specialists will be engaged to 
assist regional department staff in providing support to selected activities of national or regional 
water partnerships, which are expected to include the following:

(iii)  the Network of Asian River Basin Organizations,  established at the 3rd WWF; 
(iv)  the Gender in Water Partnership, announced at the 3rd WWF; and 
(v)  the  Mekong  Flood  Management  Partnership  among  countries  of  the  lower 
Mekong River basin, in collaboration with the Royal Netherlands Embassy in 
Hanoi and other development partners.

be provided in the proposals to be submitted by concerned departments in ADB during TA 
implementation.

20.  International and/or domestic short-term water sector specialists will be engaged on an 
individual basis to assist ADB with 
 
(i)  starting  in  interested  DMCs  the  Water  for  the  Poor—Partnership  for  Action 
launched at the 3rd WWF; 
(ii)  starting in interested cities in the region the Water for Asian Cities Program 
launched at the 3rd WWF; 
(iii)  assisting ADB to follow up on other initiatives of the 3rd WWF, such as the
